awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Frequency Quadrupled Titanium Sapphire laser for Ion, Atom and Molecule Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
High quality laser systems make possible the control and investigation of atoms and molecules with exquisite precision. This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a broadly tunable laser system which will open up large swathes of the periodic table for study. Combining the light with different elements, the PIs will conduct experiments ranging from searching for new force carrying bosons, to studying nuclear structure, and investigating molecular collisions. The instrument will enrich laboratory instruction, as undergraduate student researchers at Bucknell University and Susquehanna University will gain first-hand experience working with state-of-the art instrumentation in atomic and molecular physics.

A continuous wave (CW) frequency quadrupled titanium sapphire laser covering significant sections of the 250 to 1000 nm spectral window will be acquired and integrated into the atomic, molecular and optical (AMO) physics lab  at Bucknell University. The laser system will be used for experiments in precision isotope shift measurements motivated by searches of physics beyond the standard model, as well as molecular spectroscopy of alkali diatomic molecules with the aim of characterizing interaction strengths, collisions rates, and electronic potential energy curves. Undergraduate students from both institutions will be involved in all aspects of the experiments, gaining experience in atom, ion, and molecular spectroscopy, laser cooling, ion trapping and other skills which are central to contemporary work in AMO physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Major Research Instrumentation award was for the acquisition of a frequency quadrupled titanium sapphire laser system for use in the investigation of atomic, ionic and molecular properties via laser spectroscopy. This system has been acquired and is currently installed in the Physics and Astronomy department at Bucknell University in Lewisburg PA. The instrument has been commissioned and is now fully operational.

Laser systems such as the one described for this project are a critical component to the field of spectroscopy in physics and chemistry.  Spectroscopy studies how light interacts with the atoms and molecules that make up the matter around us.  By shining light on atomic or molecular samples, physicists can observe how matter responds based on factors such as the type of sample, the intensity of light, the color or wavelength of light, or other external factors like magnetic and electric fields.

The specific laser system in this project is ideal for spectroscopic studies for a variety of reasons. First, the color or wavelength of light produced by the laser can be selected from a broad range. The specific wavelength would be chosen very precisely and can be fixed or varied depending on the application. Second, two additional modules, known as frequency doublers, give the laser an even longer extended range of wavelengths over which to operate. Third, this laser system is very reliable and stable over long periods of time, which is ideal for sensitive measurements which capture data over extended periods of time. Finally, the brightness or intensity of the light produced allows for the investigation of more subtle effects in matter.

The system comprises a titanium sapphire ring laser, two stages of second harmonic generation, and a wavemeter. The Ti-Saph ring laser and frequency doubling stages were supplied by Spectra Physics. The ring laser has peak output power 10 Watts CW and spectral coverage 670 - 1000 nm. The doubling cavities enable optical output in blue and near UV. The wavemeter (Bristol 871) was supplied by Bristol Instruments and has a resolution of part per million at 500 nm.  

The goal of the acquisition was to enable precision spectroscopy of atoms, molecules and ions. Since its installation at Bucknell University, we have used the system for the following ongoing experiments. (1) Spectroscopy of atomic palladium for improved isotope shift measurements on the 363 nm transition. (2) Spectroscopy of rubidium and potassium as an assay for vapor cells used in alkali noble gas co-magnetometer development.

An ion trap apparatus is currently under development that will be used for spectroscopy of trapped palladium ions in PI Sulai’s lab. In addition, a heat-pipe from PI Faust’s lab at Susquehanna has been moved near the instrument. This will enable spectroscopy of alkali molecules.  Since its commissioning, the instrument has been used by Bucknell University undergraduates on research projects. We plan to integrate the instrument in upper-level experimental physics / quantum mechanics courses in our universities in the coming semesters. In making measurements using this laser system, students will be able to make more concrete connections between the theoretical content in lecture and real-world data obtained in the laboratory.
